Some bad decision may have been taken but discovered months later.  We actually do it in my company and I think the benefits outweigh the risks. It makes everyone empowered and gives high level of ownership. Also gives you the strong community feeling, people develop connections and know who to ask about what. column2: Manager in SW dev (former chief architect for a product areas)

We don't really have expertise in the matter
Teams not knowing all the stakeholders
Things that have an effect corporate wide would not get noticed. Not having a shared alignment on e.g. users, roles, security
Never ending fights of multiple strongly opiniated people
People that are not capable of this kind of responsibility. And if your to involve "all affected parties" on every decision, that might be overwhelming.
I worry about people not following the advice process and making immature decisions
Nobody will be following it up unless management tells people to do so

When you offer the whole team to possibility to offer solutions is great, I'm already doing it, but what I faced is that you find yourself in the situation that the majority of the team agree in the wrong (not best solution), because you know its better the other one and in the end you have to impose yourself, so in the end they see that their solution is not applied. But works most of the times when between all of us we get to the best solution after discussing pros and cons.  This definitely won't work for people that want to decide without any opinion, but will work for sure in a team with developers with enough experience
